Now, we've talked for years about how Sibanye-Stillwater was likely at some point to put Lonmin out of everyone's misery.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

What's unexpected is that Sibanye has moved so soon.

BE11:15am

RBC incoming.

BE11:16am

We did not expect the company [Sibanye] to act this quickly, due to: (i) the fact that it already has a purchase of concentrate agreement in place with AngloPlat; and (ii) that balance sheet is stretched following the US$2.1bn all-cash acquisition of Stillwater Mining, which completed earlier this year. As a result, our view was that Sibanye would continue a de-leveraging story and eventually make a bid for Lonmin in a few years’ time when its balance sheet was more stable. However, this morning it has announced a £1/sh all-share bid for Lonmin, or a 57% premium to yesterday’s close, valuing Lonmin at ~US$380m. We expect the deal to be approved, and it has already been recommended to shareholders by Lonmin’s board.

red bitcoin cash is where spec money flowing now and etherium. they are pushing futures here too.
fjp73 Sibanye has been on the cards for awhile, just a case of when. @BE the reason Sibanye moved (allegedly) is they were doing a cash raise of circa $170-200M and had commitments and would essentially have to pay more. Whereas Sibanye bankers are happy with the leverage on the books (I'm not) as the capex requirements for Lonmin will kick a small hole going forward.
Deep Breath everyone... So has it gone out for less than the value of Lonrho Africa (the renowned wheelbarrow maker etc)?

fjp73 @DeepBreath, yes, but as South African mining is the largest social welfare experiment on the planet, it's better they're consolidated into a tax/job/benefits system, so they can cope (allegedly)
PM11:18am

But go with GS

11:18 am
BE11:18am

We see the following potential associated risks:
a. Sibanye has acquired three new mines over the past couple of years. The integration process of those mines is still ongoing and will take 2-3 more years. This new acquisition would mean that the time to reach steady state operations could be extended by another 2-3 years, in our view, given the added scope of the integration process.

b. A potential positive for Sibanye is that it could start to process its concentrate at Lonmin and not give away a portion of its topline to Amplats for refining. In that regard, it has slight negative readacross for Amplats.
c. Lonmin’s operations burn significant cash. For Sibanye to make them cash generative, it would have to cut production which would mean retrenchments - always a challenge in South Africa given opposition from unions and the government.
4. This transaction could be a slight positive for PGMs as if Sibanye decides to close down loss-making production at Lonmin as it could potentially tighten the S-D balance.

FATDAZ @chopper bear well simple answer is 99 billion coins at 54 cents ..... this probably the coim most reminiscent of early internet stocks to me on the face of it has an interesting product but whether it will ever justify the valuation is very much open to debate
BE11:19am

And Barclays .....

BE11:19am

We believe this deal was one of the few realistic outcomes for Lonmin (4th rights issue since 2009 would not have succeeded in our view) given the going concern issues the company was facing which resulted in the delay of the FY results last month.

We believe there is clear rationale for the deal with realizable synergies (R1.5bn pa from 2021 according to management) and cost cutting potential given the contiguous nature of Lonmin’s assets to Sibanye’s Rustenburg mines (see map below), and this also provides SGL access to downstream processing assets – we value the replacement of these smelting and refining assets as at least $500m. Sibanye has stated the deal will be cash flow accretive from 2021, once all synergies are realised and related one-off costs incurred. We note 2021 is the first year where Sibanye can terminate the tolling arrangement with Anglo Platinum and use Lonmin’s smelting and refining assets for Rustenburg concentrates at much lower cost than what they are currently paying Anglo Platinum.

fjp73 What coin @FatDaz?

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Peel Hunt:

BE11:23am

Looking longer term, we could see a building need for heavy sustaining capital spend – or management choosing to shut down further shafts and shrink output again. Either way it looked like management would struggle to repay or extend the current debt facilities without a further equity raise.
Putting Lonmin into the Sibanye group means a larger parent with more robust overall cash flows that would be more capable of funding the ongoing needs of the Lonmin assets.
Given this we would accept the offer. We upgrade our recommendation from Reduce to Hold and increase our target price to 85p, the implied Lonmin price given the share ratio at the time of writing.

BE11:23am

And that's enough on smallcap rescues.

With few 2H17 new contract wins, soft pipeline momentum (£2.5bn v £3.1bn at 1H although the £0.6bn difference reflects a more conservative definition rather than LFL decline) and higher contact centre sales attrition, we cut our organic sales growth estimates for FY17 and FY18 from -1% & 0% to -2% (-4% in 2H) & -3% respectively.

BE11:32am

On the back of lower organic growth we trim EPS estimates
by 2%, 4% and 6% for FY17, FY18 and FY19. Our new PBT (adj) forecasts are £401m (same as company-provided consensus) and £409m (v consensus £417m) for FY17 and FY18 respectively.

BE11:32am

With c£0.3bn FY17 working capital outflow (partly two
terminated contracts), we now forecast £1.3bn FY17 net debt (v £1.0bn previously). This equates to 2.3x net debt/EBITDA. When including £0.1bn receivables factoring (to be paid down in FY18) and £0.3bn pension deficit, the ratio rises to 3.0x.

11:32 am

11:35 am
BE11:35am

At the Interims, management indicated that it expected year-end
net debt/EBITDA to be 2.2-2.3x post the receipt of the CAS proceeds and unwinding of the receivables financing facility (£120m at Jun-17). It is now expecting to be "around the middle of our 2.0-2.5x range..[post] unwinding of an historic seasonally favourable working capital position at the year end and some reduction in receivables financing". We expect the receivables financing balance to be c.£100m at year- end. We understand that the ending of two contracts with favourable working capital characteristics has contributed to this worse underlying performance. With a lower profits outlook for 2018, an outstanding receivables financing balance and the £67m penalty payment due to the FCA for the Connaught Income fund, a dividend cut has become inevitable. We forecast halving of the dividend, which will save c.£105m pa.

We believe visibility over a solid recovery in the second half remains low and have consequently reduced our FY18E and FY19E PBT estimates by c5% and 4%, respectively, mainly reflecting lower profits in key markets ahead. Our Dec-18 target price is reduced to 310p (from 350p) reflecting our estimate changes as well as lower multiples for the European HPC sector. Remain Neutral.

In order to reflect slightly softer trading in H1 2018 we have
reduced our FY adj PBT forecasts from £103.5m to £100.1m for FY 2018e. This means that we forecast a 1% fall in adj EPS for FY 2018e to 16.7p. We forecast 10% growth in adj PBT to £109.9m in FY 2019e.

The shares have fallen by 2% YTD and have under-performed the
FTSE All Share by 8%. The shares currently trade on 18.5x PE and 11.3x EV/EBITDA for CY 2018. Given the near term challnges in both UK and Nigeria we believe that the shares are fairly valued. We maintain our Hold rating and reduce our TP from 340p to 325p.

Following a 43% fall in the share price year to date, we upgrade to Hold from Sell. We believe the risk/reward has switched to the upside at these levels given the potential for corporate activity. We have lowered our FY18e/FY19e PBT forecasts by 5%/3% due to a weak retail market backdrop. Debenhams is still a challenged business with too inflexible a cost base and too many unanswered questions over execution and strategy. We see better value elsewhere.

The key risk to a short position from here is potential corporate activity, in our view. Having unwound long-held options, Mike Ashley now holds 21% of Debenhams ordinary shares via Mash Holdings. He has a history of buying stakes in companies and holding them. He has also shown an interest in UK department stores, having tried to buy House of Fraser in 2014, according to press reports, and still has an 11% stake.
